headline.main: Invisible Danger? Parents Look Inside the Lunchbox

docs.abstract: Parents look for ways to protect children from toxic chemicals found in consumer products; scientists urge parents not to be paranoid about products that have yet to be tested; parents find it difficult to know which changes to make; companies that specialize in environmentally friendly products using non-toxic materials, such as Seventh Generation and Cool Tote have seen boosts in sales over past five years due to fears and uncertainty; parents' buying patterns can influence companies to change materials and processes; some scientists dispute health officials' claims of safety; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: REACHING into their nylon lunch bags at school, Casey and Cameron Lilley pull sandwiches made of organic ingredients out of wax paper wrappers, and sip water from coated aluminum containers from Switzerland. Their mother, Shawn Lilley, had carefully chosen the packaging. At a recent gathering of kindergarten mothers in Seattle, Ms. Lilley told the women that chemicals could leach from plastic bags and other plastic containers into food. Since then, a few more kindergartners have shown up with sandwiches in wax paper.
docs.snippet: Many parents are changing their buying habits to try to protect their children from what they see as chemical hazards.

headline.main: Gloves On? Then It's Safe To Read This

docs.lead_paragraph: ''SANICART WIPE,'' says the little white canister positioned by the sliding front doors at the ShopRite. ''Disinfects Shopping Car Handles and Child Seats.'' People are grabbing them. First two older shoppers. Then a woman from Boonton. ''These handles,'' she says, her face drawing into an ewww. ''Everybody's touching them.''

docs.abstract: Elizabeth Weil article on wrongful-birth lawsuits being brought by parents of severely disabled children against obstetricians whom they accuse of failing to provide kind of prenatal screening and care that would have allowed them to consider having abortions; says lawsuits reflect relatively new belief that people should have right to choose which babies are born; focuses on lawsuit brought by Donna and Anthony Branca of Orangeburg, NY, who won multimillion-dollar settlement set aside for care of a son born with Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome; photo (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: Like most American women who give birth to a severely handicapped child, Donna Branca became pregnant with A.J. well before the age of 35. Had she been older, her doctors would almost certainly have recommended amniocentesis to screen for genetic disorders. But she was 31, so they did not, despite the fact that she had an unusual pregnancy. Branca bled during her first trimester, a possible indication of birth defects, and at her midterm sonogram, when she was 20 weeks pregnant, her fetus looked smaller than it should have based on when her doctors originally presumed she conceived. Branca had not gained much weight, either, but her doctors -- whom she is barred from identifying, by a legal settlement -- saw no cause for alarm. ''Looking back now, of course, it's easy to say I should have asked more questions or maybe been a little more concerned,'' she told me last fall, sitting in her grassy backyard in Orangeburg, 20 miles north of Manhattan. Branca is a pretty woman, dark and compact, with a winning suburban New York accent. She glanced at A.J., a 6-year-old with a head of dark curls and the mental capacity of a 6-month-old. Her 3-year-old twins from a subsequent pregnancy ran around collecting acorns.
docs.snippet: Legally, and morally, what does it mean to say that a child should not have existed?

docs.lead_paragraph: Apples to Apples For years, suspicion has been growing in the orchards of the Wenatchee Valley in Washington State and in the food industry at large that fruit, nature's original hand-held convenience food, is simply too poorly designed for today's busy eater. The apple, for instance: whatever it has meant to Americans over the years -- from mom's pie to the little red schoolhouse -- getting our mouths around one has also apparently meant some unspoken aggravation. Next to a banana or a grape, it's a daunting strongbox of a fruit, prohibitively so for anyone with braces or dentures; and even if you can break in, there's no guarantee a given apple will eat as sweet as it looks.

headline.main: Report Foresees No Crisis Over Aging Generation's Health

docs.lead_paragraph: The next few decades will see an explosion in the percentage of Americans over the age of 65, but the economic and social impact of this baby boomer sunset may be gentler than had been feared because of a significant drop in the percentage of older people with disabilities, a new federal study has concluded. Released yesterday, the United States Census Bureau's 243-page report on the aging population, among the largest and most comprehensive on the subject that the bureau has ever compiled, showed that today's older Americans are markedly different from previous generations. They are more prosperous, better educated and healthier, and those differences will only accelerate as the first boomers hit retirement age in 2011.
docs.snippet: The economic and social impact of an aging population may be gentler than feared since fewer older people will have disabilities.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 About 50 Kidnapped in Iraq During Bold Daylight Raid About 50 people were abducted in Baghdad by gunmen wearing the uniforms of a police paramilitary unit hours after the discovery of at least 24 bodies, all victims of execution-style slayings, Iraqi and American officials said. A1 Iraqi police units, often infiltrated and even dominated by members of sectarian militias, continue to be linked to arbitrary arrests and to the torture, rape and sometimes death of detainees, the State Department reported. A12 Attacks Shake India Holy City New details emerged of the multiple bombings in the holy city of Varanasi, India. At the same time, a Hindu-Muslim clash did not come to pass, as had been feared, despite protest marches called by Hindu radicals and their political allies. A10 Iran Blames U.S. for Impasse Iran, facing possible sanctions from the United Nations Security Council over its nuclear activities, blamed the United States for its predicament and threatened retaliation if any penalties are issued. A6 China Looks to Past for Change The Chinese Communist Party is relying on one of its oldest political tools, a Maoist-style ideological campaign, complete with required study groups, in an effort to remake itself into an efficient, modern machine and raise its public image. A1 Yemeni in Court Over Cartoons A group of 23 Yemeni lawyers denounced the editor of a Yemeni newspaper in court, during his trial on charges of insulting Islam by reprinting Danish cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad. A10 Rethinking a Unified Europe President Lech Kaczynski of Poland, who is serving as president of the European Union, has overseen a major revision of policy in the union as his conservative government no longer accepts the idea of a deeper and more integrated Europe. A12 North Korea Tests Missiles North Korea was reported to have test-fired two short-range missiles within its borders, even as six-nation talks over its nuclear program remain deadlocked. A8 NATIONAL A14-21 3 College Students Held In Alabama Church Fires Three college students from the prosperous suburbs of Birmingham, Ala., were arrested in the burnings of nine Baptist churches last month in rural Alabama that federal officials say was a prank that spun out of control while the students were deer hunting. A1 Former Mayor's Trial Nears End After a seven-year investigation that has already led to the convictions of 10 people, a jury will now decide whether former Mayor Bill Campbell of Atlanta was at the center of that corruption. A14 Jews Delay Vote on Gays A committee of legal experts who set policy for Conservative Judaism decided at a closed-door meeting in Baltimore to wait until December to vote on whether to lift the movement's ban on gay rabbis and same-sex union ceremonies. A18 Tape Shown at Terrorist's Trial Prosecutors seeking the death penalty for Zacarias Moussaoui played a videotaped statement in which a member of an Islamic radical group testified that Mr. Moussaoui had visited him in Malaysia in 2000 and said he had a dream to fly an airplane into the White House. A16 A Vote to Ban Lobbyist Gifts Facing accusations that lawmakers are not serious about breaking the tight bond between Capitol Hill and K Street, the Senate voted unanimously to bar members of Congress and their aides from accepting gifts and meals from lobbyists. A21 F.B.I. Wiretap Violations Found The Federal Bureau of Investigation found violations of its own wiretapping and intelligence-gathering procedures more than 100 times in the last two years, and problems appear to have grown more frequent in some important respects, according to a Justice Department report. A21 Bush Urges Aid for Louisiana President Bush demanded that Congress provide Louisiana with the full $4.2 billion he had requested in housing aid for the storm-battered state, even as the House and Senate began considering whether some of that money should go instead to other states in the region. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Housing Agency Proposes New Fees to Narrow Deficit The New York City Housing Authority is facing a budget shortfall of $168 million and has proposed narrowing the gap by charging residents new fees and increasing old ones for owning a dishwasher, getting a toilet unclogged or running a washing machine. A1 Plastic Bags Out of the Oven Health concerns are being raised over sous vide, in which food is cooked with herbs in airtight plastic bags. New York City inspectors say the popular cooking method could make food prone to bacterial contamination, and have told chefs to halt the practice until they have a government-approved plan for it. A1 Snapple Synergy Falls Short The Bloomberg administration acknowledged that its innovative venture to let Snapple sell beverages in city-owned buildings in exchange for cash and tourism promotion had fallen far short of its goals. B1 No Penalty for Deputy Chief The Civilian Complaint Review Board has charged a deputy New York police chief with abuse of authority for ordering the arrest of a woman during the 2004 Republican National Convention. But the police commissioner decided against disciplining him. B1 SPORTSTHURSDAY D1-6 HOUSE & HOME F1-12 THURSDAY STYLES G1-12 ARTS E1-12 OBITUARIES C18 Tsegaye Gabre-Medhin An acclaimed Ethiopian playwright who was also the country's poet laureate, he was 69. C18 Richard Kuklinski A Mafia hitman called the Iceman, who claimed to have killed more than 100 people, he was 70. C18 BUSINESS DAY C1-17 Gabelli Faces Fraud Claims The Justice Department announced that it planned to pursue civil fraud claims against a famed money manager, Mario Gabelli, contending that he orchestrated a scheme to deceive the Federal Communications Commission in its auctions of wireless spectrum several years ago. C1 Decline in Soda Sales Under increasing fire from critics who blame it for contributing to America's looming problem of childhood obesity, the number of cases of soda sold in the United States has declined, data released by Beverage Digest shows. C1 Revival of Withdrawn Drug A federal advisory panel unanimously recommended that the multiple sclerosis drug Tysabri, which was withdrawn about a year ago for sometimes causing a deadly brain disease, be returned to the market. C2 Testimony in Enron Trial Andrew S. Fastow, a former chief financial officer of Enron, provided strong evidence to link Kenneth L. Lay, the company's founder and former chief executive, to conspiracy to defraud investors. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: The death of the intelligence panel; facing facts on Iran; a baseball tragedy. Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert. headline.main: Soda Sales Are Showing Their Age

docs.lead_paragraph: The next generation may not be the Pepsi generation -- or the Coke generation, for that matter. For years, soda has been the quintessential American drink, considered the perfect thirst quencher, morning pick-me-up or accompaniment to lunch or dinner.
docs.snippet: As Americans look for greater variety in their drinks and strive for healthier diets, consumption of soda is slipping.
